title: Camber Castle Walk Route

nearby.description: Rye Harbour To Winchelsea Beach Walk

images.title: Camber Castle by Julian P Guffogg, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Camber Castle. The finished castle was initially equipped with 28 brass and iron artillery guns and a garrison of 28 men, commanded by a captain. It may have seen service in 1545 when a French fleet attacked the coast, but its operational value was short lived.

images.title: Grazing land north of Camber Castle by Richard Law, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

images.title: Dave Bushell / Pasture near Rye
images.caption: Pasture near Rye. Looking North across sheep pasture between Camber Castle and Rye.

images.title: Mervyn Rands, CC BY-SA 4.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The ruins became a popular spot for picnics in the 18th and 19th centuries, and was painted by J. M. W. Turner. It is now protected as a Grade I listed building.

images.title: Inside Camber Castle by Julian P Guffogg, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Inside Camber Castle

description: This walk visits the 16th century Camber Castle in Rye, East Sussex. The historic site is located in the Rye Harbour Nature reserve just to the south of the town. You can follow a section of the Saxon Shore Way to the castle from Rye town centre. It's about a 1.5 mile walk along the waymarked trail passing through the Castle Water Nature Reserve on the way. There is a bird hide just east of the castle on the Castle Water Lake where you can look out for a variety of water loving wildlife. The ancient Device Fort was built by King Henry VIII to protect the Sussex coast of England against the increasing risk of a French attack in 1539. English Heritage provide guided tours if you would like to explore the interior of the fort and learn more about its history. You could continue your walking in the area by heading north east to Camber Sands where there is a popular beach.
